conclusion: A metal rod slides along horizontal rails from position ab to position a'b'. The rod has resistance R. The rails have negligible resistance. The rod moves at speed v₁ in one case and v₂ in another, with v₁:v₂ = 1:2. The crossed (×) symbols indicate a uniform magnetic field pointing into the page.

premise: When a conducting rod moves through a magnetic field, an EMF is induced according to Faraday's law. For a rod of length L moving with velocity v perpendicular to a magnetic field B: EMF = BLv.
The current in the circuit will be determined by the induced EMF and the total resistance (which is just R since the rails have negligible resistance): I = EMF/R.
The external force needed to maintain the uniform motion must balance the magnetic force on the rod. The magnetic force is: F = BIL. The power of this external force is: P = Fv = BILv.
conclusion: P₁ = BLI₁v₁ = BL(BLv₁/R)v₁ = B²L²v₁²/R and P₂ = BLI₂v₂ = BL(BLv₂/R)v₂ = B²L²v₂²/R
Ratio of loop currents: I₁:I₂ = 1:2. Ratio of powers of the external forces: P₁:P₂ = 1:4
